skill.name: pylabrobot
skill.description: Laboratory automation toolkit for controlling liquid handlers, plate readers, pumps, heater shakers, incubators, centrifuges, and analytical equipment. Use this skill when automating laboratory workflows, programming liquid handling robots (Hamilton STAR, Opentrons OT-2, Tecan EVO), integrating lab equipment, managing deck layouts and resources (plates, tips, containers), reading plates, or creating reproducible laboratory protocols. Applicable for both simulated protocols and physical hardware control.
skill.summary: Laboratory automation toolkit for controlling liquid handlers, plate readers, pumps, heater shakers,...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation/prompt-based skill containing only markdown reference files with Python code examples. No executable scripts, no network calls defined in skill files, no file system access capabilities. All capabilities are legitimate laboratory automation operations described for educational purposes.

content.value_statement: Automate complex laboratory workflows with a unified Python interface. Program liquid handling robots, integrate plate readers and lab equipment, and create reproducible protocols that work across Hamilton STAR, Opentrons OT-2, and simulated environments.
actual_capabilities: Program liquid handling robots (aspirate, dispense, transfer, mix)
Manage deck layouts and laboratory resources (plates, tips, containers)
Integrate plate readers (BMG CLARIOstar) and analytical equipment
Control heater shakers, incubators, centrifuges, and pumps
Simulate protocols with ChatterboxBackend before running on hardware
Visualize deck state and track tip/liquid volumes in real-time
limitations: Hardware backends require physical device connection
Some features (Tecan EVO, flow cytometers) are work-in-progress
Opentrons backend uses older HTTP API with limited features

use_cases.title: Automate sample preparation
use_cases.description: Program automated pipetting protocols for ELISA, PCR setup, and sample transfers across 96 and 384-well plates

use_cases.title: Integrate lab equipment
use_cases.description: Coordinate liquid handlers with plate readers, heaters, and centrifuges for end-to-end automated workflows

use_cases.title: Create reproducible protocols
use_cases.description: Develop and validate protocols in simulation, then deploy to Hamilton STAR or Opentrons OT-2 hardware

prompt_templates.title: Basic liquid transfer
prompt_templates.scenario: Set up a simple plate-to-plate transfer
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PyLabRobot protocol to transfer 100 ÂµL from source plate wells A1:H1 to destination plate wells A1:H1 using a Hamilton STAR. Include tip pickup, aspirate, dispense, and tip drop operations.

prompt_templates.title: Serial dilution
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a PyLabRobot script for 2-fold serial dilution across 8 wells of a 96-well plate. Use 8-channel pipetting and include mixing steps between transfers.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-device workflow
prompt_templates.scenario: Integrate heater shaker and plate reader
prompt_templates.description: Combine liquid handling with incubation and reading
prompt_templates.prompt: Develop a PyLabRobot workflow that transfers samples to a plate, incubates on a heater shaker at 37Â°C with shaking, then reads absorbance on a BMG CLARIOstar plate reader at 450nm.

prompt_templates.title: Simulation testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PyLabRobot protocol using ChatterboxBackend for simulation. Set up tip tracking, volume tracking, and the visualizer to test a complete protocol before deploying to physical Hamilton STAR hardware.

output_examples.input: Create a protocol to transfer 50 ÂµL from well A1 to well B1 using Hamilton STAR
output: Tip rack and plate assigned to deck positions
Picked up tip from position A1
Aspirated 50 ÂµL from source well A1
Dispensed 50 ÂµL to destination well B1

best_practices: Always test protocols in simulation (ChatterboxBackend) before running on physical hardware
Enable tip tracking and volume tracking for accurate state management
Save deck layouts and states to JSON files for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Running protocols on hardware without first validating in simulation
Skipping error handling for device connection and cleanup operations
Not accounting for temperature equilibration time in incubation steps

faq.question: Which liquid handlers are supported?
faq.answer: Hamilton STAR/STARlet (full support), Opentrons OT-2 (supported), Tecan EVO (work-in-progress), and Hamilton Vantage (mostly supported).

faq.question: Can I test protocols without hardware?
faq.answer: Yes, use ChatterboxBackend for simulation. It validates protocol logic, tracks tips and volumes, and works with the visualizer for real-time feedback.

faq.question: How do I integrate multiple devices?
faq.answer: Create separate device instances (LiquidHandler, PlateReader, HeaterShaker) and coordinate them through async Python code. Use try/finally blocks for proper cleanup.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: This is a prompt-based skill with no code execution. All protocols run locally using the pylabrobot Python package. No data is transmitted externally.

faq.question: Why is my Opentrons connection failing?
faq.answer: Verify the robot IP address is correct, ensure network connectivity, confirm the robot is powered on, and check that no other software is blocking the HTTP API port.

faq.question: How does this compare to Opentrons API?
faq.answer: PyLabRobot provides a unified interface across multiple robot platforms. The same protocol code can run on Hamilton STAR, Opentrons, or simulation by simply swapping the backend.
